key_points: U.S. consumer spending rebounded in March, rising 4.2% amid a surge in income due to government COVID-19 pandemic relief money.
Labor costs surged by the most in 14 years in the first quarter, indicating increased wage growth as companies compete for workers.
The U.S. saw a significant fiscal stimulus of $1.9 trillion from the White House and rapidly improving public health conditions.
Consumer spending, a major part of U.S. economic activity, is expected to further accelerate in the second quarter.
Personal income boosted by 21.1% in March, helped by one-time $1,400 stimulus checks, leading to a saving rate soar to 27.6%.
The government's expansion of the COVID-19 vaccination program and fiscal generosity are lifting consumer spirits.
Wage increases are expected to sustain consumer spending even as the stimulus effect fades.
The Employment Cost Index saw a significant jump, indicating rising wages and potential labor market tightness.
Inflation is warming up, with the core PCE price index increasing 1.8% in the 12 months through March.
Economists expect robust consumer spending and economic growth, with projections for growth of at least 7% in 2021.
spokespersons: Brendan Coughlin (Head of Consumer Banking, Citizens in Boston)
Sarah House (Senior Economist, Wells Fargo in Charlotte, North Carolina)
